reviewText:
This is one of the best movie remakes of a classic TV show that I have ever seen.  In the movie, the salt-of-the-earth Clampetts discover oil, get fabulously rich, and move to Beverly Hills.  Jed Clampett (played by Jim Varney) is in search of a wife to help raise Ellie Mae to be a real lady, but the family must beware of evil people who want to steal their wealth. Now, perhaps that sounds a little far fetched, but if you've ever met some simple folk who come into a lot of oil money, the whole story sounds very, very close to home.
The casting is superb -- there are cameo appearances by Dolly Parton, Zsa Zsa Gabor, and Buddy Ebsen.  Lily Tomlin is hilarious as the familys secretary, and Jim Varney actually plays a very believable straight guy.  This movie has no sex, foul language, or violence, and will bring lots of laughs to the whole family.

This is the familiar parody in which a 60s/70s TV show takes place in the 90s, a formula utilized two years later in THE BRADY BUNCH MOVIE. Film however suffers from very few laughs since the sitcom wasn't very funny to begin with, and there isn't enough story here to carry about two hours worth of film. It tells of Jed Clampett, a primitive old hillbilly who strikes oil in his old country household and decides to "load up the truck and move to Beverly (Hills that is...swimming pools, movie stars). You can pretty much write the film after this.

I've gotta say first off, that I never liked the TV show at all...so when this movie came out in the early 90's, I didn't exactly rush out to see it.  First saw it on TV (there was nothing else on that night).  What a wonderful surprise!  The cast is uniformily excellent...they all stood out.  When we got the video, we watched it twice in one evening with the kids.  I loved Diedrich Bader as a hopelessly dimwitted Jethro; Lily Tomlin as a smitten but efficient Miss Jane Hathaway; Dabney Coleman was PERFECT as the investment banker; Rob Schnieder is at his weasily best (ya gotta love the part where he wrecks the entire office!) as the employee out to defraud Jed Clampett, who is played perfectly by the late great Jim Varney.  I thought the storyline - especially making Elly May into a teenager entering high school - was terrific!  Also who could forget the cameos by Buddy Ebsen and Zha Zha Gabor?  There are so many laughs, this is a film worth viewing again and again!
Like "The Addams Family" films, the movie remake of "The Beverly Hillbillies" is superior to the TV show.  Highly recommended!

This movie was a great verson of the 60's sitcom.  The only person who  wasn't perfectly casted was the woman who played Ms. Hathaway, and even she  had very few flaws!  The only thing keeping this from 5 stars is the guy  who sang the theam song.  He wasn't as good as the guy who did it in the  60's.

This was a replacement for my worn out VHS. Jim Varney was great in this role as Jed Clampet. A rare view of a more (slightly) serious side to the man. Cloris Leachman, who I typically don't like as an actress  was also surprising in her role as "Granny". Unlike most remakes, this version of The Beverly Hillbillies stayed reasonably true to the original TV series.

Released in 1993, The Beverly Hillbillies is a cinematic version of the hit TV series that ran for a decade from 1962-1971. The story details the family of hillbillies from the Ozarks striking it rich and moving to Beverly Hills where they're strangers in a strange land.

Ive never really watched the TV series, although Ive of course seen clips here and there. Unlike 1994s The Flintstones and 1995s The Brady Bunch Movie and their sequels, The Beverly Hillbillies isn't nearly as effective, not even close. The cast is good and there are amusing moments, but once the family moves to Southern California the story is uninvolving and you find yourself biding time waiting for the next gag. Sometimes its downright bad, but theres enough good to glean for a mildly fun time. Lily Tomlin, Erika Eleniak, Lea Thompson and Leann Hunley are enjoyable.

The film runs 92 minutes and was shot in Beverly Hills, Pasadena and Los Angeles, CA.

GRADE: C (a very weak "C")
Far, far cry from the original.

"The Beverly Hillbillies" is one of the funniest movies I have ever seen. Of course nowadays people frown on movie adaptations. But this might make them change their minds. Just like the series it's about a Midwestern man and his family who move to California after striking gold. This movie however adds something more to the plot, an attempted embezzlement led by a bank tycoon (Rob Schneider) and his girlfriend (Lea Thompson). With an ensemble cast featuring Jim Varney, Deidrich Bader, Chloris Leachman, Erika Elineak and Lily Tomlin. This movie is downright fun, and despite several flip offs it's good family fun.
I highly recommend it.

This adaptation of the 1960's hit series, The Beverly Hillbillies, now as a motion picture. The Beverly Hillbillies get translated with the late Jim Varney as Jed (God rest his soul and his heart), Cloris Leachman as Granny, Diedrich Bader as Jethro/his sister, Jethrine, Erika Eleniak as Ella May, Dabney Coleman as Mr. Drysdale and Lily Tomlin as Ms. Hathaway. With Lea Thompson as Rob Schenider as the crooked con artists, Laura Jackson and Woodrow Tyler and special cameos by Dolly Parton and the late, original Jed from the series, Buddy Ebsen as his Barnaby Jones character from his series. From the director of the hits, The Little Rascals and the original Wayne's World movie. This movie gets much better and funnier doing each repeat viewing, this is pretty much a overlooked, underrated TV Adaptation from the 1960's hit an series. Watch this and when you're done watching it for the first time, watch it again and again and again till you can't laugh anymore! Besides the DVD comes with no menu at all, it just repeats it again as the only bonus feature! I found this adaptation very well done and very underrated at most despite the bad reviews but it didn't hold the film down from being a success at the box office!
We enjoyed watching this movie as a family. Very funny. Would reccomend as a family movie. Great value at this price.

I saw this movie when it first came out and laughed. It was great to see Jim Varney in a role that people didn't make fun of him. A smart and sensible character that headed his family to Hollywood to have a "proper bringin' up fer his daughter" Little did they all know that Jed couldn't have been so wrong. She was brought up in the mountains with the love and support of every down home person that came into their lives. It became a lesson for Hollywood to learn from such down home folk.

This movie guides the viewer to humor, heart touching stories of family and the temptation of greed in the outside world and how the simple life can always win. Call me redneck then I am proud to be one.

I got mine today didn't really think this movie was gonna be any good consedering how its a remake of a tv show which normally sucks this movie really met my expectations. It told the story quite well not exact but close enough. I like how it is made in our century. Including: the use of cell phones and celebritys of our time even though we've gotten more hi tech since this was released.. this movie was funny and great for the whole faimly I recommend it:)
I didn't have very high expectations for this movie, but I was pleasantly surprised. It was funny and mostly true to the original (more innuendo though). Jethro is the only one I felt was miscast.

I saw this movie when it came out and was absolutely dissapointed.  Surprisingly Jim Varney did a pretty decent job playing Jed.  There was no hint of "Ernest" in his character - not that I dislike Ernest but he's not Jed Clampett.

 But that's the ONLY good comment I can make regarding this film.  As others have stated, the people who made this movie had no real understanding of the original TV show.  Jed was uneducated but wise and absolutely incorruptable.  Jethro was a dumb but very likeable character who approached every new interest with wild enthusiasm.  He was dumb but never silly.  The Jethro in this movie was so silly as to be unwatchable.  Ellie Mae was always pure and sweet.  In this movie they have her chewing tobbaco and spitting on people.  It was offensive to call this actress Ellie Mae.  Grannie wasn't too bad but still not close to the original.  I supsect this movie will only appeal to the casual fan of the TV show - the people who saw it every now and then in re-runs but don't really know the characters.  I fail to see how anybody really familiar with the original could even sit through this.  The pitiful Jethro was the complete deal breaker for me.  Max Baer's Jethro was in my opinion equaled only by Don Knott's Barney Fife as one of the two greatest TV comedy characters.  This movie's Jethro was as funny as watching paint dry in comparison.
funny movie, really loved it

This movie is trully based on the show done in in the 1960's.  What is really nice is that there is no verbal profanity.  Giving the finger and making a joke out of it is actually kind of funny - another plus for the movie.

This is simply the worst form of cashing in on a franchise ever.  The writers, directors and producers must have never seen the original show.  This movie captures absolutely none of the charm of the original.  It's a simple humor-less mockery.  Spend your money on the original show, especially the first couple seasons, which were pure genius.  Every actor in this debacle has great talent, they just aren't allowed to show it here, in this very stiff, very calculated, very poor copy of a great premise.  It's like the fifteenth generation of a bad copy, totally distorted and unrecognizable.  How Buddy Ebsen agreed to appear in this is beyond me.  He must have really needed a payday.  Cloris and Dabney are so far above this trash, they should have sued for defamation of career.  Lily Tomlin's worst performance ever!

Ever since I was a kid, I've loved this movie Everbody did an awesome job, and was a great tribute to the classic series! When Jed Clampett is hunting, he accidentally finds oil, and is given 2 billion dollars. He takes Elly May, Granny, and Jethro to Bevery Hills to live the sweet life. When arriving at their mansion, Miss Hathaway thinks they are criminals, because of the way they dress. After everything is sorted out, Jed wants to get married. He falls in love with a beautiful con artist named Laura Jackson, who is only after his money. Soon, it's up to Granny and Miss Hathaway to stop the wedding. I highly recommend THE BEVERLY HILLBILLIES!!!

Yall come back now, ya hear?

My son loves the original television series, so it was natural for me to buy this movie for him.  We have enjoy watching it several times together, and it is great to see decent humor like this together.
I've seen the movie before amd loved it.  One evening I happened to think of it and realized I could probably find it on Amazon.com.  I wasn't disappointed.  The movie is hilarious.
Not very well written, humor is not so humorous, but its saving grace is that it has lots of well known, very talented actors.

The Beverly Hillbillies with Jim Varney is excellant. Just like most of his films. I am pleased to have it in my film collection. It is sad however the Mr. Varney is no longer with us. He is one of my favorite comedians. The film is very funny and enjoyable and I will always get enjoyment from watching it.

This movie made a mockery out of the TV series and undermined the original characters.  The characters in the TV series were backwoods and nieve, however very loveable, funny, and a pleasure to watch.  The characters in the movie cannot be connected to the TV series in any way.  The real Jed Clampett would not have been taken in by some floozy bimbo to the point that Miss Jane had to save his fortune.  There's no way the real Granny would have been kidnapped and held in a rest home against her will.  Jethro was so silly until he wasn't funny at all and Ellie Mae didn't have her critters that she loved so much in the TV series.  The real Mr. Drysdale guarded the Clampett's forturne with his life and wouldn't let anyone come near it.  This movie was a huge disappointment.  Save your money and watch the reruns.

I disagree w/ other commenters that this movie had "dirty parts".  OK, it wasn't Pollyanna; there were a few PG13 moments, but nothing to make you send the kids outta the room.  They had to add a LITTLE spice, GEEZ!! It was made in 1993-far past the age of innocence! Anyhoo, the characters-
JIM VARNEY as JED-SHOCKINGLY WELL DONE, and VERY ENDEARING!  I really wish he hadn't died, there's no telling what else he could have done.
CLORIS LEACHMAN as GRANNY-OH MY LORD, how is it possible to put into words WHAT A GREAT JOB SHE DID!  The word HILARIOUS just doesn't cut it!  Dare I say, SHE WAS A BETTER GRANNY THAT THE ORIGINAL, IRENE RYAN?  THERE, I SAID IT!  Whew, what a relief! I mean it too!
DEIDRICH BADER as JETHRO-VERY FUNNY!  DIFFERENT than Max Baer, for sure, but still VERY FUNNY!  Those big horse teeth really added to the redneck effect.  I really loved the part when he & his mom Pearl were flying down the road, and she asked him didn't he order the new brakes yet, and he said "sure I did Maw, they're coming in next week"!  He was funny as Jethrine too, although maybe just a little too pretty (?) (best movie line:"C'MON CITY BOY, LET'S DANCE!" I LOVE THAT!)
ERICA ELENIAK as ELLIE MAE-did a good job, pretty true to the character, although I couldn't get over how bushy her eyebrows were, but I guess that added to the hillbilly effect.  She is a VERY pretty lady.
LILLY TOMLIN as MISS JANE-NAILED IT, NAILED IT, NAILED IT!!!!!!!!!!!
the same for DABNEY COLEMAN as MR. DRYSDALE, and whomever that was as MRS. DRYSDALE, and also the lady who played COUSIN PEARL.  The rest of the cast-well, not very important.

What can I say??? "The Beverly Hillbillies" is the funniest

movie ever! I'm not talking "KANGAROO JACK" funny, or "Ernest

rides again" funny, NO! I'm talking 11 OSCAR winning funny!

And the cast was perfect! Jim Varney as Jed, Deidrich Bader as

Jethro, Erika Eleniak as Elly May, Cloris Leachman as Granny,

and Lily Tomlin was an extra treat as miss Hathaway!

But, there was something different about it. Instead of the

family freindly jokes, they relied on ADULT humor! Can you

believe they said the word "SEX" in the beverly hillbillies

of all things!??!?!?!?!?

So I would not recommend it to anyone who liked the TV series

as a kid. This is a DIRTY, VULGAR movie and I cringed when I

watched this!

Still it's a reeeeeeaaaaaaly funny movie!

don't waste your time watching this HORRIBLE, AWFUL movie!!! The acting, the dialouge, the direction, the casting...all HORRIBLE!!! This, along with "The Honeymooners" "The Dukes of Hazzard" and countless other movies that are based on TV shows, should be held up as prime examples as to why certain shows should never get the big-screen treatment. However, there is one bright spot: Lily Tomlin as Jane Hathaway, she captures the character perfectly, the way Nancy Kulp did in the classic TV show. But, the all-time worst performance is,without a doubt, Diedrich Bader (Oswald from "The Drew Carey show") as Jethro.

Don't waste money on this movie!!! Instead buy the DVDs from MPI. I'm just glad I didn't buy this, and instead rented it.

Captures none of the folksy comedy of the original series instead relying on bathroom humor.  Don't waste your money or time.  Spend your money on the TV series instead.  Only thing worth mentioning is Lily Tomlin as Jane Hathaway who almost captures to a T the characterization of the original Nancy Culp.  Otherwise, this one's a turkey and Jed would be a-shootin it!

Yes, to quote Madea Simmons from "Diary of a Mad Black Woman," this movie is a rag. It is one of the worst movies I have ever seen in my entire life; it's trash, pure and simple. The acting is terrible and plus, it demeans the original (and classic!) television program. I wouldn't waste your time. Go out and buy the real TV Show and get your money's worth.

I grew up watching the original Beverly Hillbillies so I was thrilled when this one came out.  Jim Varney does a great job in the part of Jed.  The other characters are also wonderful.  It was a lot of fun to watch.

Good:

It's good to see that the old TV series has not been forgotten.

Erika Eleniak as Elly Mae and Dabney Coleman as Mr. Drysdale do good jobs with what they have to work with.

Bad:

Jim Varney as Jed plays his part totally straight - no humor from the star of the famous "Ernest..." movies.

Cloris Leachman plays Granny well, but they give her nothing but silly slapstick comedy to do.

Diedrich Bader as Jethro plays a stupid idiot rather than a naive country boy.

Lily Tomlin as Jane Hathaway does a good job, but she hogs every scene she's in and looks dumb in a blonde wig.

Rob Schneider - why is he even IN the movie? His character should have been cut out all together.

Lea Thompson pretending to be a French tutor helping Elly Mae become a lady, just so she can get at Jed's money, is extremely ANNOYING.

Summary:

I love the TV series and even the worst episode is better than this entire movie. They failed to capture the spirit and gut-busting humor that made the original so successful.

Sorry Penelope Spheeris but you can't. Most evident in the scene when the Clampetts give the finger to those people on th efreeway. Varney is too short to replace tall Buddy Ebsen as Jed. Film still has almost the heart of the original.

This 1993 movie based on the classic 60's TV show is one of the best of these kind of movies based on a tv program.

It's the same story, A man named Jed, who was a poor mountaineer who barley kept his fammily fed, then one day he was shooting at some food, when up from the ground came a bubbling brew. Well the next thing you Jeds a millionaire and his kin folk said "Jed, move away from there. California is the place you outta be, so they loaded up the truck and moved to Beverly Hills. Where they gots movie stars, smog and cement ponds.

And once Jed and the familly have settled into there new house there whacky adventure starts. Jethro (The guy from Drew Carey show) becomes Vice PResidant at Mr. Drysdales bank and starts looking for a wife for his uncle. Lea Thompson (Back To The Future) & Rob Scnieder(The Animal) play the villains of the movie. Miss Laureda (Lea) is setting herself up to steal Jed Clampet's (Jim Nabours, Ernest) money. But miss Hathoway (Lilly Tomlin) is on the case with Granny (Leachman) to proove there frauds.

There is lots of Zaney goofy fun a long the way. Also a guest role appreaence by original TV series Jed, Buddy Ebson and the lovely Dolly Parton. Also a few other known faces during the ride.

Theres no bonus features, so don't pay much for it. But check it out of you wanna have a a good ol hayseed rockin', boot-scootin, wei doggy of a time.

well now it's time to say goodbye to this reveiw. I hope you folks learned something new. Your all invited back to this web site locality. To read a heap more reveiws about the Beverly Hillbillies.

Ya'll come back now, ya hear

I had to admit that the casting in this movie was nearly perfect. Almost perfect with one exception...Jim Varney.  Not the fact he's a bad actor or too associated with Ernest, but because he was really too young.  Still, he wasn't bad (you know what I mean?) and the story was funny.  Not too much different from the TV show, just in color and a little more risque.  Came out in a period where old sitcoms were being made into movies, and this one was better than the others.

I just like to watch Jim Varney play Jed Clampet. The Movie is funny and reminds me of the old tv series alot. Plenty of action and comedy the very thing Varney was good at. If you watched the Hillbillies as a kid you need to see this movie, I'm glad its finally coming out on dvd. Ill be on the waiting list.

This film was based on the sitcom of the same name which ran on CBS from 1962 to 1971. Like in the opening montage of the sitcom,Jed Clampett(the late Jim Varney) struck oil on his small farmland. That happened by accident,of course. He was "shooting at some food",as sung on the opening theme. "And up thru the ground came a bubbling crude",is the following line. "Oil that is,black gold,Texas tea!",is the following line. So Jed,his mother-in-law Daisy "Granny" Moses(Cloris Leachman),Jed's daughter Elly May(Erika Eleniak) and Jed's nephew Jethro Bodine(Diedrich Bader) all pack their belongings and head for beautiful Beverly Hills,California. Granny was very content in the Ozark Mountains where this family moved from. Their new next door neighbor is the family's banker Milburn Drysdale(Dabney Coleman). Unfortunately Milburn's wife Margaret couldn't stand Jed and his clan. She thought they were downgrading Beverly Hills. Lily Tomlin is Jane Hathaway,an employee at the Commerce Bank of Beverly Hills,where Milburn is president. Jane and Jethro are romantically involved at a few points in the film,just like the sitcom. One memorable scene is where Dolly Parton as herself,sings "Happy Birthday To You" at Jed's birthday party. Rob Schneider,late of Saturday Night Live,and Lea Thompson are two devious business people who are out to get Jed's multi-million dollars. Thompson's character was engaged to Jed and at the wedding ceremony,her and her partner's plan is carried out. Then they are both arrested. Another memorable scene is where,when Jed and his clan are enroute to Beverly Hills,another driver "flips the bird" to them. Jed and his clan all do the same to another driver who verbally abused them. The only two survivors of the sitcom cast are Donna Douglas,who was Elly May, and Max Baer Jr. who was Jethro. The only sitcom cast member to appear in this film was Buddy Ebsen,who played the star character,Jed. Ebsen reprised his post-BH title role,Barnaby Jones. Ebsen passed away in July 2003 at age 95 after a long illness.

Like my headline says "It's about time"  I love this movie and the characters in it.  I could never find this movie on tape and cannot wait for it's release on dvd.  PLEASE release more of Jim Varney's "Ernest series" on dvd.

I would recommend this movie gets put on dvd.  I really enjoyed the movie with Jim Varney.  I had started a dvd collection and I have been watching for this to come available on dvd for quite some time.  I think it is a really funny remake.  And I would recommend this movie to everybody who loves Jim Varney as I do!  I would also like to add that Lilly Tomlin and the rest of the cast were excellent in their protrayal of the orginal characters in the tv series.  I have to admit I was very surprized as to how well Jim Varney played Jed in this movie.  He had to follow Buddy Epson, whom is an excellent actor, as Jim Varney I believe, if had he lived longer, he would of shown us his real tallents.

Jethro Bodine: Jed Clampett has all of the 3 A's. He's A-ttractive, A-vailable and A-billionaire.

Beverly Hillbillies, The (1993) Jim Varney, Erika Eleniak, Lily Tomlin, Dabney Coleman, Cloris Leachman, Diedrich Bader, Lea Thompson, Rob Schneider, Buddy Ebsen, Dolly Parton, D: Penelope Spheeris. From the TV show of 1962 arrives the big-screen update, with the Clampett clan striking oil in the Arkansas boondocks where they turn billionaires and move to Beverly Hills (?swimming pools and movie stars?), falling target to calculating Schneider and his wife Thompson. The cast matches the old faces and is greatly enjoyable (Tomlin is good as Miss Jane Hathaway and Leachman is a spitting image of Granny), but they try too hard to mock the former hillbillies . . . it?s modernized into a big mess. The cornier script is cluttered with physical comedy and dialogue that?s given half a brain, and above all, sex jokes are added in by four writers and given a final approval by a female director (why carp?)! Running Time: 93 minutes and rated PG for adult humor.

This is one I save for time requiring sheer silliness with no observable traces of reality. I have to admit that it is a very contrived and predictable plot, but anything that is such an obvious spin-off of a fabulously popular television series would have a hard time being anything but derivative. Having said all that, I laughed all the way through the movie, and still chuckle thinking about a lot of the slapstick shtick used so liberally here.  The storyline has been updated to make it a bit more topical, and the characters as depicted in the movie are slightly more contemporary than their counterparts in the TV series. But they are just as refreshingly corny and ordinary, and sometimes that is such an invigorating act to watch that it seems liberating somehow.
The cast is uniformly terrific; the best is easily the late Jim Varney, showing surprising range in his star-turn recreating the Jed Clampett character in the shadow of the legendary Buddy Ebsen, who so many of us baby-boomers remember as being Jed Clampett.  Of course, Cloris Leachman shows why she is such a celebrated actress in her hilariously naughty portrayal of Granny, and Erika Eleniak gives a wonderfully corny interpretation of sexy but innocent Elly Mae, more interested in ?rasslin? than boys, and as quick to ?whup? those boys if they get our of line.
Also quite good is Diedrich Bader as Jethro (and also acting in drag as Jethro?s sister Jethrine, on the make and virtually unstoppable), as is Dabney Coleman as Mr. Drysdale, and a wonderful Lily Tomlin as Miss Hathaway. Of course, the villains are key in all this, and Rob Schneider and Lea Thompson spread their wings into comedic farce quite well. The scene with Thompson vamping Jed Clampett with her false French accent is hilarious for its ?shocking? unintended double-entendre, and is typical of how funny this movie is at times.  As I said earlier, I save it for comic relief when I really yearn for mindless yucks, and it never fails me. Come on down and take a dip in the cement pond. I reckon you?ll find it powerful entertaining. Enjoy!

If I could give zero stars I would. I ordered this specifically for bushwhacked as my family loves this show but our copy was damaged. It arrived finally and I guess since its foreign sold it won't play in any dvd player( I tried five different players). So dissatisfied.

You can't replace the original cast of "The Beverly Hillbillies", but if you're going to do a movie "remake", this is about as good as you could do.

Cloris Leachman channeled Irene Ryan to perfection.

Jim Varney didn't try to channel Buddy Ebsen, and that was for the best. It would have never worked. However, he captured the quiet and naive dignity of Jed Clampett very successfully.

Ellie May is probably the least challenging of the roles, and Erica Eleniak did a good job.

Dabney Coleman was the perfect "type casting" for Drysdale. All he had to do was give his normal sleazy businessman performance, and he delivered.

Lily Tomlin was a bit over the top as Jane Hathaway, but that's what you expect, and what you get, from Lily Tomlin.

The only casting I thought missed in big way was Diedrich Bader as Jethro. I just never bought his characterization.

The plot hit on several tropes from the early years of the TV show, and I enjoyed that:
* turning Ellie May into a lady
* Jed finding a mother for her
* unscrupulous people out to swindle Jed
* the whole "fish out of water" genre treatment

It's all there. Don't take it seriously, and enjoy the spirit that particularly Varney and Leachman infused this film with.
